ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt about the challenges we are facing as a collective in terms of climate change
Pollution and natural resource depletion from the economic side.
Insights in the general economic principles of pollution mitigation, models for efficient use of renewable and non-renewable resources.

I gained knowledge about pollution abatement, nonrenewable and renewable resources and how society and governments manage them economically. I learnt about how bodies tackle issues like climate change from an economics standpoint, and how they plan out the best option given the financial costs.

I did not develop many skills during this course, but I developed some knowledge about pollution and renewable and nonrenewable resources. I did not think this class was taught the greatest, and I wish we would have learned more useful information about like math for the Psets during class.
I learned a lot about pollution and mitigation and the steps that we can take in the future so that be don't burn out all of our resources prematurely.
I learned a lot about how economic theories and equations can be applied to the environmental studies and how we can improve our environmental conditions
information that challenged my previous understanding of what we should do for climate mitigation. i now see all sides of the issue
Knowledge of techniques and economic methods used to evaluate the value of environmental problems/phenomena.
general information about different types of problems with natural resources and pollution.
I learned a lot about resource management and pollution.
I learned a couple quantitative ways to economically approach natural resource management, but mostly learned qualitative approaches.

I developed a new way to approach topics related to the environment that focuses on finances and practicality. As an EVST major, this is a very useful class that gives perspective and teaches skills related to economics that I didn't have before. I never took microeconomics, and while it would have been very helpful it wasn't absolutely necessary. the biggest takeaway is to consider all impacts of a policy, such as when people say it would be best to have zero pollution, that's actually not the case because of the many costs related to that which aren't environmental.
q
Nothing, one of the worst classes at Yale

I learned a lot about how Economics pertains to our daily lives in taking care of our environment. As an economics major, I had never looked at our environment through that close of a lens before, so it was very rewarding being able to dive into these subtopics of environmental conflicts.
Learned a great deal about environment and natural resource management through the lens of economics. In addition to the economic skills, insightful context of natural resources was taught.
Decisions to make on the environment
Economics of natural resources and how to regulate them, such as water, forests, etc.
Nothing
Understanding the effect the environment has on the economy and its implications
Very little.

I initially took this course because I was interested to learn more about the correlation of renewable resources and economics. However, the course is much more extensive than that, and was quite interesting overall. Topics such as cap-and-trade, taxation on pollution, and recycling are all covered.

Learned a high level overview of main topics in environmental economics. Covered a lot of different methods for different environmental issues but the actual application in the problem sets involved really simple math.
forestry, water economics, optimal abatement and mitigation, non renewable and renewable resources and their respective managements
Nothing
I learned how to value public goods instead of private ones.
How to label economic variables as trees to make it environmentally related.
A good overview of environmental economics
How to manage reaources effectively, best mitigation for global/local pollutants etc.

the nuances of placing a value on resources and our attempts to solve things like emission damage, water reallocation, and climate change; the trajectory of climate change and possible economic responses

I learned the economics of natural resources 

using marginal cost and marginal benefit to evaluate the optimal level of abatement for emissions pollution

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the material is not complex to understand and the psets are relatively short. The content covered in the lectures is the same as the slides. If you have a good TA, the discussion section can be interesting at times.  Weaknesses: The lectures and psets are entirely different, and so are the exams. The material is sometimes contradictory and confusing and seems outdated.

Strengthes: interesting and important topics. Weaknesses: lecture was not very engaging, psets were all math but lecture was nothing like them at all. Only way to do the pset Wass from TAs helping explain them. Midterm was also so much harder than anything we had learned.

The course is well structured thematically and the problem sets help to understand the concepts. However, the psets often required information that was not given during the lecture or on the main slides, but only in the TF sessions. This made independent preparation more difficult. The goal of covering all a wide range of ideas and concepts also meant that the content was very superficial and economics-centric. As an environmental science student, it was often very frustrating to have very little space for discussion.
Strengths are that it's an interesting course, teaching students real life examples and encourages action.
Need more instruction and relation between the psets and the material learned in class, they did not correlate that well.

Strength - very prevalent to correct society
Weakness - found it difficult to do the problem set sometimes because if felt separate from the lectures that were being taught in class.

The course was interesting but I found that most of what is discussed in lectures are not transferable to the problem set assignments. Because of this, there was a disconnect in a lot of the topics discussed in the lectures

strengths: lectures were very to the point. not much grey area on slides.
weaknesses: class was sometimes wasteful as the presentation was over and the professor kept rambling on about irrelevant information just to fill time. midterm was very random and had intentionally difficult wording to confuse students as opposed to testing knowledge

One strength is definitely the professor and how he puts the material across. I feel that the course is designed well and the material is not too overwhelming. However, exams could be designed a bit better given that they cover really specific types of problems and don't really test a general understanding of a course.

Weaknesses: content in class did not always match the exams, especially the math was extremely hard to connect the concept from class and psets to the tests. The math portion of both exams seemed completely different and I never knew how to approach them despite actually studying really hard. Waste of my time studying for it .

The course was split up well with a good amount of time given to each of the three main topics. An issue was that we did not go over lots of math in the course, but the problem sets were exclusively math, which made it a bit difficult to get a grasp on what we should know for tests.

Strengths: The TF team

Weaknesses: This class content was way too easy which resulted in the exams (specifically the math) being focused on tricky problems that were more focused on novel solutions rather than being actually diagnostic of our grasp of the course content. The math simply needs to be made harder, not more tricky. This method of examination undermined the learning of the rest of the course, students could completely check out and then were only focused on the review sessions at the end of the course where they attempted to get everything they could out of the TFs. Required sections were not useful and only were when Ken ad-libbed and taught us extra interesting topics.

I was incredibly disappointed with this course. The lectures often obscured the important information to the point that the material we covered in section almost always felt entirely new. The graphs, opinions, and figures given in class were hardly - if ever - backed up by real world data (especially compared to other Econ classes I have taken at Yale which have relied on FRED, the BLS, and more). Any time a question was raised, the professor simply deferred back to what he had stated on his lecture slides. The professor had us turn in our problem sets on paper during class and often started class while people were still turning in their assignments, meaning no one could hear him over the ruffling of papers. Class often started late and almost always ran over time.

the topics were interesting but it could have been taught a lot better. lectures were dry and unengaging. psets felt like they came out of nowhere compared to what we did in class and were SUPER unorganized. some of the information on the lecture slides were outdated by many years. having two exams be the majority of the grade was not an effective way to evaluate learning in the course. it was also strange that the midterm was so early in the semester. I would have more midterm, or biweekly quizzes, or something that counts participation because there were many people that never showed up anyways, and you didn't even have to because the professor just read off of the slides basically. no one did the readings even though they were interesting, they were just way too long and only provided useful context, you definitely didn't need them to do well in the class. there weren't that many great resources to prepare for the exams. practice questions would have been super useful. also, recording the lectures so that we'd be able to go back over them.
q
Overall idea is good, but the course is taught so badly. Prof has no idea what he is doing, he is so disorganized and makes it hard to have any engagement
Lecture was interesting, the PSets were engaging and really tested whether or not I knew the math concepts.

The strengths of this course was that the sections clarified information from lecture, but also taught new information that is helpful for both content and for solving problem sets. The TA's were also very helpful for the problem sets. Also, the content of the lectures was, generally, relevant to present day. 

One weakness of the course is that there were times that the slides were hard to understand, or hard to determine the main takeaways. Perhaps a clearer explanation of those slides or written bullet points on those slides that clarify the takeaways would help.
The content is very interesting but the course as a whole is not well organized so its hard to learn from it
Good sections, class could have been more interesting
The class was very well organized and the lectures and sections were very engaging.
The lectures and TF sections did not match the psets and often I was left to figure out how to solve things by myself
The course was pretty disorganized and was difficult to understand what seemed to be a bit of a disconnect between section material and lecture material.
This course is terribly organised. Many of Professor Mendelssohns slides are completely outdated and teaching was an h engaging combination of soliloquy and overly wordy slides.
Lectures were straightforward and would be tested via psets
Weakness: Not enough practice material for exams
Too many problem sets

The problem sets were super easy and did not take much time to complete. The lectures were all pretty interesting but sources were rarely provided for the charts and graphs which usually looked like they were made by the professor. The professor tended to mix facts and his own opinions in the lecture so it was important to remain skeptical

strength: the curse topics are interesting and the TAs are knowledgeable and invested 

weakness: the course is very disorganized, the Professor makes little to no time to help students understand the material outside of lecture, the psets are not similar to what we learn in lecture, the professor is not careful enough to take the time to write a new exam and basically copied the same questions from the previous year (some students had access to it somehow and had an advantage over everyone else)
More relevant curriculum

The course work and problem sets were unorganized and riddled with typos. The concepts were not difficult but often it was incredibly unclear what instructions were asking. The course moved slowly which was nice at times.

Strengths: content
Weaknesses: course organisation + exams (no access to past papers, answers to midterm released too late)
Its a good class.

While course content was incredibly relevant to today's world, attending lectures does not translate directly to our abilities to solve the PSETs. Without the right TA it's really difficult to get through a lot of these PSETs because not all the equations are very clearly provided in class. The PSETs sometimes were unclear, especially the Excel PSETs, which the TAs had to clarify during their sections. As a whole, attend the sections. Sections are more important than lectures. Also, I wish the PSET solutions were posted because it was hard to understand where I went wrong sometimes. Would also make studying feel more legitimate.

i wish there was more access to practice questions before exams 

the problem sets were not indicative of the problem set questions on the exam 

Mathematical teaching burden fell onto the teaching assistants 

the professor never looked at students in the back of the room and he rarely looked at students beyond the first 5 rows of seating. it prevented my engagement and deterred many students from attending lecture. He hardly acknowledged anyone but those seated right in front of him. It was a poor method for fostering a learning environment.

strength: I enjoyed the lecture style 

weakness: unorganized, assessments did not do a good job of evaluating course knowledge/engagement

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend only if youre looking for a low workload course and dont care about the material not being engaging at all.
Probably not. It's pretty gutty but with the huge discrepancy between lectures/psets and how hard the exams are out of nowhere I don't think it's ultimately worth it

As an environmental science student, I would only recommend this class if you are looking for an insight into how the environment, pollution, and finite resources are viewed from an economics lens and have capacity to accept that certain concepts are not being discussed or heard.
I would recommend this to another student. It offers a fine introduction to environmental studies whilst building on previous economics principles.
I would recommend this course if the student needs an easier elective for econ, the workload is small and there is not too much information that needs to be learned.
Yes, I really enjoyed the class overall.
Yes it was interesting to learn how economic theories can cross over and be applied to environmental purposes

no. very random class, no one has any idea what's going on, professor makes midterm unnecessarily hard, problem sets did not cover anything we went over in class (could not complete problem set without going to office hours and having TA's help with answers)
No

his is one of the more relaxed Econ electives, so if you're looking for an easier Econ elective I'd suggest taking this one. It isn't stressful to too much work and all. I'd highly recommend taking it if you just want to learn more about environmental problems and common cultural misconceptions we have regarding the environment.

Not really. If you credit D it then yes, but it's very hard to feel prepared for the exams. During the semester the workload was low but it was impossible to study for the exams as we had no idea what to expect and the questions on the exams were either super specific or just very different from what we had learned.
I would recommend this course only if you are interested in the topics because otherwise, it might be a bit boring.
No, easy but surely not a fun experience
No; see comments above.

i'm not sure, because the material is so interesting but it's really not taught well, which is such a shame. honestly, I would still have taken it because I learned things that will be super useful to me but overall it was annoying how unorganized it was. I also felt like some of the content was pretty difficult and not explained that well.
yes
I would not. It is a gut because there is no work and the psets are easy, but exams are so vague it is impossible to do well
Yes, I learned a lot about concepts that no other Yale class I have taken has touched upon.
Yes, this course is interesting, as it applies economic concepts to environment and nat res management.
I would not recommend this course.
Yes. This class had a very manageable workload and a very interesting curriculum.
Yes, to learn about the environment
Yes, it is very interesting to learn about how natural resources relate to economics and how to efficiently regulate them.
No, it wasnt well taught or very interesting
For an Econ credit, yes, but it was not the most organized course and the professor was not seemingly enthusiastic about teaching.
Not at all. Professor is not captivating in lecture, problem sets and exams were poorly written, one of the worst classes Ive taken.
Dont take this if youre looking to be engaged
Yes but the content is not easy however the workload is low
Definitely would recommend if youre interested in environmental economics. Its not difficult although the exams were always surprisingly kind of tough though manageable.

No, the material is interesting but the course is not structured to facilitate learning. The professor is extremely knowledgeable but he dedicates little time to make the material approachable and organized. He would at times distribute psets with errors (which happens of course), but he would also hand the TAs wrong answer keys and expect them to handle it. If Professor Mendelssohn is teaching it, please do yourself a favor and take another environmental economics class
No
It is a good econ elective if the environment is somewhat interesting to you.
If you need an economics gut, yes. If you want to learn interesting environmental economics, no.
Yes
Yes

Yes. The content is very relevant to the current state of the world and is insightful. That being said, you should probably have the basic economics courses down; I can imagine someone who may struggle if they don't already understand things like MC, MB, and MD. With the right TA you will be fine.
Not really. It may be a gut, but you dont learn much. It really isnt worth your time.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. The course was interesting and engaging at some points. There were dull moments in lecture but that is to be expected in any class. fascinating material covered. very useful knowledge gained from this class
